section.title: Introduction
section.para: Introduce generic nature of joint probability requirements, referring to factors involved in the transformation of rainfall to runoff, and other factors (eg initial reservoir level or tide levels) that may influence the design performance of interest. Outline the need to focus on as few factors as possible, the different approaches to characterisation, and the derivation of exceedance probabilities.

section.title: Selection and treatment of factors
section.para: Describe use of sensitivity analysis to identify the factors of most importance to the problem. Emphasise the importance of selecting as few factors as possible, the potential for dependence between factors, and the likelihood of their dependence on event severity.

section.title: Stochastic sampling
section.para: Describe different methods of stochastic sampling: bootstrap sampling from ensembles, non-parametric, and parametric approaches. Discuss random number generation, the generation of correlated variables, and conditional sampling.

section.title: Estimation of Exceedance Probabilities
section.para: Discuss the two main approaches to deriving frequency curves based on direct sampling and stratified sampling. Discuss how large sample sizes allow the use of simple frequency analyses (compared to procedures presented in Book 3), and describe Total Probability Theorem for analysis of stratified solutions, including mention of importance sampling.

section.title: Worked Examples
section.para: Provide worked examples for sampling, construction of frequency plot, and analysis of a stratified sample.
